dublinCore.dc:title: 114 HR 1352 IH: Student Loan Borrowers’ Bill of Rights Act of 2015
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Ms. Wilson of Florida introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce, and in addition to the Committees on Ways and Means, the Judiciary, and Oversight and Government Reform, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To establish student loan borrowers’ rights to basic consumer protections, reasonable and flexible repayment options, access to earned credentials, and effective loan cancellation in exchange for public service, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Student Loan Borrowers’ Bill of Rights Act of 2015.

title.header: Borrowers’ Right to Basic Consumer Protections

section.header: Dischargeability of student loans in bankruptcy cases
section.text: Section 523(a) of title 11 of the United States Code is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking paragraph (8); and
by redesignating paragraphs (9) through (19) as paragraphs (8) through (18).

section.header: Reinstatement of the 6-year Statute of Limitations for student loans
section.text: Subsection (a) of section 484A of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1091a(a)) is amended to read as follows:

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any Federal or State statutory, regulatory, or administrative limitation on the period within which debts may be enforced—

paragraph.text: an institution that receives funds under this title may file a suit or initiate or take another action for collection of a refund due from a student on a grant made, or work assistance awarded, under this title, during the 6-year period beginning on the day after the refund first became due (exclusive of period during which the State statute of limitations otherwise applicable to a suit under this paragraph would be tolled under State law);

a guaranty agency that has an agreement with the Secretary under section 428(c) may file a suit or initiate or take another action for collection of the amount due from a borrower on a loan made under part B during the 6-year period beginning on the day after such guaranty agency reimburses the previous holder of the loan for its loss on account of the default of the borrower (exclusive of period during which the State statute of limitations otherwise applicable to a suit under this paragraph would be tolled under State law);

an institution that has an agreement with the Secretary pursuant to section 487 may file a suit or initiate or take another action for collection of the amount due from a borrower on a loan made under part D or E after the default of the borrower on such loan during the 6-year period beginning on the day after the date of the default of the borrower with respect to such amount (exclusive of period during which the State statute of limitations otherwise applicable to a suit under this paragraph would be tolled under State law); or

the Secretary, the Attorney General, or the administrative head of another Federal agency, as the case may be, may file a suit or initiate or take another action for collection of a refund due from a student on a grant made under this title, or for the repayment of the amount due from a borrower on a loan made under this title that has been assigned to the Secretary under this title, during the 6-year period beginning on the day after the refund or the amount first became due.

section.header: Prohibition of collection of student loans through certain offsets or through wage garnishment

subsection.header: Prohibition on offset of social security benefits
subsection.text: Section 3716(c)(3)(A) of title 31, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (i), by striking except as provided in clause (ii) and inserting except as provided in clauses (ii) and (iii); and
by adding at the end the following new clause:

clause.text: Notwithstanding clause (i), any payments due to an individual under Federal benefits programs cited under clause (i) shall not be subject to offset under this subsection if the offset is for payments certified by the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1070 et seq.).

subsection.header: Prohibition on offset of tax refund
subsection.text: Section 3720A(a) of title 31, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Any Federal agency and inserting (1) Except as provided in paragraph (2), any Federal agency; and
by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

Any past-due legally enforceable debt owed by an individual to the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1070 et seq.) shall not be subject to notification under paragraph (1), and any refund of Federal taxes paid by the individual shall not be subject to reduction under subsection (c) for such debt.

subsection.text: Section 3720D(a) of title 31, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Notwithstanding and inserting: (1) Except as provided in paragraph (2) and notwithstanding; and
by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

Any delinquent nontax debt owed by an individual to the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1070 et seq.) shall not be subject to collection under this section through garnishment of disposable pay of the individual.

title.header: Borrower’s Right to Reasonable and Flexible Repayment Options

section.header: Exclusion from gross income for discharge of student loan indebtedness

subsection.text: Paragraph (1) of section 108(f) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking if such discharge and all that follows and inserting a period.

Paragraph (2) of section 108(f) of such Code is amended by striking made by— and all that follows and inserting the following: . Such term includes indebtedness used to refinance indebtedness which qualifies as a student loan under the preceding sentence..
Section 108(f) of such Code is amended by striking paragraphs (3) and (4).
The amendments made by this section shall apply to discharges of indebtedness after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: 529 plan distribution for student loan payments

subsection.text: Subparagraph (A) of section 529(e)(3) is amended by striking clause (iii) and inserting the following new clause:

clause.text: interest or principal paid with respect to a qualified education loan (as defined in section 221) with respect to a designated beneficiary.

paragraph.text: Section 529(e)(3)(A) of such Code is amended by striking the second sentence.
Section 72(t)(7)(A) of such Code is amended by inserting determined without regard to subparagraph (A)(iii) thereof after section 529(e)(3).
Section 530(b)(2)(A)(i) of such Code is amended by inserting determined without regard to subparagraph (A)(iii) thereof after section 529(e)(3).

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to distributions made after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Inclusion of Parent PLUS Loans in Repayment Programs

subsection.text: Section 455(d)(1)(D) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1087e(d)(1)(D)) is amended by striking , except that the plan described in this subparagraph shall not be available to the borrower of a Federal Direct PLUS loan made on behalf of a dependent student;.

paragraph.text: Section 493C of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1098e) is amended—

clause.text: by striking this section and all that follows through hardship and inserting In this section, the term partial financial hardship; and
by striking, (other than an excepted PLUS loan or excepted consolidation loan);
in paragraph (1), by striking (other than an excepted PLUS loan or excepted consolidation loan); and
in paragraph (6)(A), by striking (other than an excepted PLUS loan or excepted consolidation loan); and

subparagraph.text: in subsection (c), by striking (other than an excepted PLUS loan or excepted consolidation loan),.

paragraph.text: Section 455(d)(1)(E) of such Act (20 U.S.C. 1087e(d)(1)(D)) is amended by striking , except that the plan described in this subparagraph shall not be available to the borrower of a Federal Direct PLUS Loan made on behalf of a dependent student or a Federal Direct Consolidation Loan, if the proceeds of such loan were used to discharge the liability on such Federal Direct PLUS Loan or a loan under section 428B made on behalf of a dependent student.

subsection.text: The income-contingent repayment plan (based on the President's Pay As You Earn repayment initiative) implemented in parts 674, 682, and 685 of title 34, Code of Federal Regulations, as amended by the final regulations published by the Department of Education in the Federal Register on November 1, 2012 (77 Fed. Reg. 66088 et seq.), shall be available to borrowers of—

paragraph.text: a Federal Direct PLUS loan made on behalf of a dependent student; and
a Federal Direct Consolidation Loan, the proceeds of which were used to discharge the liability on a Federal Direct PLUS Loan or a loan under section 428B made on behalf of a dependent student.

subsection.header: Loan forgiveness for service in areas of national need
subsection.text: Section 428K(a)(2) of such Act (20 U.S.C. 1078–11(a)(2)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (A), by striking (other than an excepted PLUS loan or an excepted consolidation loan (as such terms are defined in section 493C(a))); and
in subparagraph (B), by striking (other than an excepted PLUS loan or an excepted consolidation loan).

section.text: Section 428B(a)(1)(A) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1078–2(a)(1)(A)) is amended by striking regulations promulgated by the Secretary and inserting section 685.200(c) of title 34, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on September 30, 2011).

title.header: Borrowers’ right to a meaningful degree

section.header: Prohibition on suspensions of professional licenses for loan default
section.text: No evidence of an individual’s default on the repayment of a loan made, insured, or guaranteed under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1070 et seq.) may be admitted into evidence in a Federal or State proceeding involving the individual’s professional or vocational license.

section.header: Prohibition on loss of access to transcripts for loan default
section.text: Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1094(a)) (as amended by section 301) is further amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

subparagraph.text: The institution will not prohibit a student from accessing the student’s transcripts, degree scrolls, or other certifications of coursework or educational attainments at the institution because the student is in default on the repayment of a loan made, insured, or guaranteed under this title.
For purposes of this paragraph, the term student includes former students.

title.header: Right to effective loan cancellation for borrowers engaged in public service careers

section.header: Extension of loan cancellation for borrowers employed in public service jobs for 5 years
section.text: Section 455(m) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1087e) is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.text: Beginning fiscal year 2016, the Secretary shall also cancel 50 percent of the balance of interest and principal due on any eligible Federal Direct Loan not in default for borrowers employed in a public service job for 5 years during the repayment of such loans—

clause.text: by substituting 60 for 120 each place it appears; and
by substituting October 1, 2007 for October 1, 2015; and

subparagraph.text: by applying paragraph (2), by substituting 50 percent of the balance with the balance.
